Obama calls for unity in speech

Weather Wisdom

Significant snowfall ahead

As a winter storm moves into the region later today, some areas near the coast could see 6-12 inches of snow, David Epstein writes. (Boston.com, 4:09 p.m.)
  • Watch WBZ Accuweather forecast  |  Details
Complete Boston.com StormCenter coverage

UMass-Amherst student killed in fire

A male student died after a fire erupted at an apartment complex that's used for off-campus housing by nearly two dozen students, a fire official said. (AP, 2:46 p.m.)

Shooting erupts after Martin Luther King Jr. Day parade in New Orleans

The five teens wounded near an intersection where a parade passed earlier do not have life-threatening injuries, police said. (AP, 3:46 p.m.)
  • Hundreds urged to honor MLK Jr.'s legacy in Boston

Plymouth nuclear plant taken offline

The Pilgrim Nuclear Power Station shut down the plant today to investigate what it called a minor leak at a valve on a pipe that carries steam. (Globe, 2:22 p.m.)
  • 1/11 Pilgrim shut down after recirculation pumps turn off

Game over? Atari files
for Chapter 11 bankruptcy

The video game maker's US operations have filed for protection in an effort to separate from their parent company. (AP, 1:51 p.m.)

Fire damages Dorchester warehouse

A three-alarm fire broke out at the Logan Furniture warehouse on Freeport Street just after midnight, officials said. No one was injured. (Globe, 11:20 a.m.)

Price paid for not running ball

There will be a rush to put this latest failure at the feet of Tom Brady, but the lack of a balanced attack is the reason the Patriots fell to the Ravens.

Helmet joins fight vs. head injuries

Former Harvard quarterback Vin Ferrara started Xenith LLC to make high-tech football helmets that attempt to minimize the possibility of concussions.
Opinion | Juliette Kayyem

Action on guns, immigration needed

The success of Obama’s domestic agenda in his second term depends on playing to both red states and the blue ones.

In surveillance, a new ballgame

Boston firm Bounce Imaging is developing a ball with six cameras inside for 360-degree viewing that can be used as a surveillance device for emergency responders.
Opinion | John E. Sununu

A crisis of values at MIT

As Aaron Swartz faced jail time, MIT remained silent. What happened to the clever, rebellious school?

End-of-life care rarely discussed

Despite expert recommendations meant to encourage talks about end-of-life care, many still do not spend their final days the way they would have chosen.
